Citation.Paragraph:
This paper is presented as a contribution towards a revision of the subfamily
Myrmicinae in the Ethiopian zoogeographical region. The subfamily
Myrmicinae is by far the largest and most diverse in the region (and the world), containing some 43 genera in sub-Saharan Africa at present. These genera can be categorized roughly as small (1 10 species), moderate (10 - 40 species) and large (more than 40 species). The vast majority of Ethiopian region myrmicine genera fall into the small category (29 genera), about nine genera come in the moderate category and only five reach the final category, of which three (
Tetramorium Tetramorium Mayr,
Pheidole Pheidole Westwood and
Crematogaster Crematogaster Lund) are huge, with well over 100 species each in the region. A good indication of distribution of genera on a world basis is given by Brown (1973
Citation.Name: Brown

Citation.Paragraph: and a discussion of the most prevalent ant genera is presented by Wilson (1976
Citation.Name: Wilson

Citation.Paragraph:
In the original description of this remarkable ant I placed the genus tentatively in the tribe
Meranoplini . I am aware now that this move was incorrect and that
Ankylomyrma Ankylomyrma is not close to
Meranoplus Meranoplus or any other member of that now-disbanded tribe (for discussion see Bolton, 1981
Citation.Name: Bolton

Citation.Paragraph: Ankylomyrma coronacantha Ankylomyrma coronacantha Bolton , 1973
Citation.Name: Bolton

Citation.Paragraph:
Atopomyrmex Atopomyrmex is a small genus of strongly polymorphic arboreal ants. The two species included,
Atopomyrmex mocquerysi mocquerysi and
Atopomyrmex cryptoceroides cryptoceroides , nest in the wood of standing trees and forage arboreally, frequently coming down the trunk but only rarely venturing onto the ground. Arnold (1916
Citation.Name: Arnold

Citation.Paragraph:
points out that
Atopomyrmex mocquerysi mocquerysi is usually carnivorous and, when disturbed, exudes a whitish secretion from the anal glands. Nests are made in hollow stems or rotten parts of standing timber but it is not known if the species tunnel their own galleries or take over the galleries of termites and boring beetles. Of the two species
Atopomyrmex mocquerysi mocquerysi is very widely distributed, being found in wooded and forested areas almost throughout sub-Saharan Africa; Wheeler (1922
Citation.Name: Wheeler

Citation.Paragraph:
The genus most closely related to
Atopomyrmex Atopomyrmex is the Ethiopian and Malagasy genus
Terataner Terataner . Differences separating them, and other related genera, are noted in the discussion of
Terataner Terataner (p. 290). At its inception
Atopomyrmex Atopomyrmex contained only
Atopomyrmex mocquerysi mocquerysi . Soon afterwards
Atopomyrmex cryptoceroides cryptoceroides was added and this was followed by a number of others, added later by several authors. Later still these extra species were progressively removed from
Atopomyrmex Atopomyrmex until the present time, when
Atopomyrmex mocquerysi mocquerysi and
Atopomyrmex cryptoceroides cryptoceroides are again its only members. These species, originally described in
Atopomyrmex Atopomyrmex but now placed elsewhere, are as follows. The species
Atopomyrmex alluaudi alluaudi Emery,
Atopomyrmex bottegoi bottegoi Emery,
Atopomyrmex foreli foreli Emery,
Atopomyrmex luteus luteus Emery,
Atopomyrmex scotti scotti Forel, and
Atopomyrmex steinheili steinheili Forel were transferred to
Terataner Terataner by Emery (1912
Citation.Name: Emery

Citation.Paragraph:
nodifier Emery was originally made type-species of genus Atopula Emery but is now included in
Tetramorium Tetramorium Mayr, see Bolton (1976
Citation.Name: Bolton

Citation.Paragraph:
Atopomyrmex selebensis selebensis Emery was made type-species of
Dilobocondyla Dilobocondyla Santschi, by Santschi (1910
Citation.Name: Santschi

Citation.Paragraph:
Atopomyrmex escherichi escherichi Forel was transferred to
Dilobocondyla Dilobocondyla by Forel (1913
Citation.Name: Forel

Citation.Paragraph:
Known from two species, the minute ants of the genus
Baracidris Baracidris seem to be endemic in the wet forest zones of West and Central Africa where they inhabit the leaf-litter and topsol layers. The genus most closely related to
Baracidris Baracidris is
Adelomyrmex Adelomyrmex Emery whose known distribution includes the Neotropics, New Guinea, Fiji and Samoa. One of the African species was wrongly referred to
Adelomyrmex Adelomyrmex in an earlier publication (Bolton, 1973
Citation.Name: Bolton

Citation.Paragraph: Cyphoidris spinosus Cyphoidris spinosus Weber , 1952
Citation.Name: Weber

Citation.Paragraph: Ocymyrmex Ocymyrmex Emery, 1886
Citation.Name: Emery

Citation.Paragraph: This easily defined and spectacular genus, which has not been revised previously, is confined to the Ethiopian zoogeographical region where its 23 species inhabit dry to semi-desert conditions in the eastern and southern parts of the continent. All the species nest directly into the ground, either in the open or at the bases of plants. In the former case the nest is usually in sandy soil and a crater is formed around the entrance hole. Arnold (1916
Citation.Name: Arnold

Citation.Paragraph: who was acquainted with and reviewed the South African species, pointed out the remarkable swiftness of these ants, saying that for speed they far outstrip ' all other ants with which I am acquainted, so much so that they appear almost to fly over the surface of the ground'. Prins (1965
Citation.Name: Prins

Citation.Paragraph: In the classification of both Emery (1922
Citation.Name: Emery

Citation.Paragraph: and Wheeler (1922
Citation.Name: and Wheeler

Citation.Paragraph:
the genus
Ocymyrmex Ocymyrmex is the sole constituent of its own tribe, the
Ocymyrmecini , and Kugler's (1978
Citation.Name: and Kugler's

Citation.Paragraph: Arnold (1916
Citation.Name: Arnold

Citation.Paragraph: and Emery (1922
Citation.Name: and Emery

Citation.Paragraph:
both recorded that no females of
Ocymyrmex Ocymyrmex had ever been found, but they were both aware of the presence of strange variants in a number of nest-series which had transverse sculpture on the head instead of the usual longitudinal form. Several of these variants were described from isolated examples as separate species or subspecies, despite the fact that long ago Arnold (1916
Citation.Name: Arnold

Citation.Paragraph:
Discounting synonyms and infraspecific forms the genus
Pristomyrmex Pristomyrmex contains about 38 named species to date. Of these names five valid species belong to the Ethiopian region (see below), six to Australia (Taylor, 1965
Citation.Name: Taylor

Citation.Paragraph: and two to the Malagasy region (Brown, 1971
Citation.Name: Brown

Citation.Paragraph:
The genus most closely related to
Pristomyrmex Pristomyrmex is the monotypic
Perissomyrmex Perissomyrmex Smith (1947
Citation.Name: Smith

Citation.Paragraph:
281), which differs mainly in having the antennae with only 9 segments, as opposed to 11 in
Pristomyrmex Pristomyrmex .
Perissomyrmex Perissomyrmex was based on a couple of specimens intercepted in quarantine in the U. S. A., ostensibly on a ship from Guatemala. But, although Kempf (1972
Citation.Name: Kempf

Citation.Paragraph: Arnold (1952
Citation.Name: Arnold

Citation.Paragraph:
proposed a subgenus of
Terataner Terataner which he called
Tranetera Tranetera , erected to include only the species
Terataner bottegoi bottegoi and
Terataner transvaalensis transvaalensis , with the former nominated as type-species. In the same paper he chose to treat Atopula Emery as a subgenus of
Terataner Terataner . It has since been shown (Bolton, 1976
Citation.Name: Bolton

Citation.Paragraph:
Terataner Terataner belongs to a group of genera which also includes the African genus
Atopomyrmex Atopomyrmex Andre , the Oriental / Indo-Australian genus
Dilobocondyla Dilobocondyla Santschi and the predominantly Australian genera Dacryon Forel,
Peronomyrmex Peronomyrmex Viehmeyer ,
Podomyrma Podomyrma F. Smith and
Pseudopodomyrma Pseudopodomyrma Crawley (Taylor, 1970
Citation.Name: Taylor
